docs.lead_paragraph: No matter what happens on the golf course, this year's United States Women's Open is certain to be unusual. Rarely does the Open feature someone who is 13 years old, or someone who is eight months pregnant. But while young Morgan Pressel and the mother-to-be Brenda Corrie Kuehn will garner much attention this week, expect familiar names like Annika Sorenstam, Karrie Webb, Dottie Pepper and Se Ri Pak to play prominent roles when the tournament begins on Thursday at Pine Needles Lodge and Golf Club.

headline.main: Children of All Ages Will Be at the Women's Open

docs.abstract: United States Women's Open golf tournament will feature familiar names as well as 13-year-old Morgan Pressel and Brenda Corie Kuehn, who is eight months pregnant (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Shannon White used to assume she would become a teenage mother, like her big sister. But at 17, after three years in an experimental afterschool program intended to prevent teenage pregnancy, her expectations are quite different. ''I wasn't thinking about college when I was young,'' she said. ''But I changed when I was about 14. This program changed me. I have a life. I have things to do. I'm going to be a nurse. Will I have babies? No time soon.''

headline.main: Program Finds Success in Reducing Teenage Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Teenage-pregnancy prevention program created by Dr Michael Carrera at Children's Aid Society is singled out as solid success in report by National Campaign to Prevent Teen Pregnancy; program offers not only traditional sex education, but also tutoring, SAT preparation, job skills, medical and dental care and sports and creative arts; three-year evaluation of its 12 sites in poor neighborhoods nationwide found participants had one-third fewer pregnancies and births than those in control group; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Powell Fails to Persuade NATO on Antimissile Plan Secretary of State Colin L. Powell encountered a hard wall of opposition to President Bush's plan for a missile defense plan when he appeared at a meeting of NATO foreign ministers. He could not even convince them that their countries faced the threat of missile attack. A14 Senator Joseph R. Biden, Democrat of Delaware, said he would broaden debate over the Bush plan after he becomes Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman next week. A10
